awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Affordable Daily Activity Assistive Robots for Individualized Elderly Care in Community Based Long-term Care Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project addresses the healthcare crisis of the growing elderly population coupled with low birth rates where the number of older adults is outgrowing the number of working-age adults to care for them. With the scarcity of care options available, robots are a welcome solution for assisting elders with small tasks that would normally be done by a caregiver. These robots would serve in an estimated 17,000 elder care facilities nationwide. Robots will be able to identify elders and personalize their assistance while monitoring health parameters. Critically, this work will aim to understand how a robot capable of assistance in simple activities of daily living should behave to aid elders in a community long term care setting including the acceptance and willingness to receive assistance from the robot.

The proposed project addresses three research areas: 1) Robot Design for Elderly: How can we develop a useful affordable robot system for the elder-care community?  What is the elder-care community preference for humanoid robot forms over non-humanoid in a robot that provides assistance?  2) Robot Behavior for Elderly: How will the elderly react to an autonomous robot that can recognize individuals, call them by name and provide services? What effects will different designs have on the interaction such as form-factor, motions, expressiveness and modalities of interaction? 3)  Robotic Health Tracking of Elderly: As interactions with the robot occur in social settings, the robot can log data such as requests for water delivery from the robot, distance walked by the elders etc. What factors affect the quality of data can be obtained and how useful will this data be to clinicians? These questions will be answered by building a low cost robot using a variety of technologies developed from NSF-funded programs, then validating the performance with tests in an elder-care facility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the needs of the growing older adult population in community settings. In particular, we aimed to learn how an affordable socially assistive robot (SAR) can help in adult day centers aiding care givers by interacting with the older adults, promoting physical exercise, social interaction and hydration while maintaining health logs of the older adult interactions. The number of older adults is outgrowing the number of working-age adults to care for them. In the US alone, the number of those over age 65 is projected to double from year 2000 to 2030, reaching 71.5 million.  With the scarcity of care options available, robots are a welcome solution for assisting elders with small tasks that would normally be done by a caregiver. The planned research thrusts focused on three questions: 1) What is the preference for humanoid forms over non-humanoid forms in a robot that provides assistance in communal older adult settings? 2) What are the efficacy and design issues for face recognition and calling older adults by name during robot modalities of interaction. 3) Determine the factors that affect the quality of logged data and the usefulness of this data to clinicians. We were able to address the first, but the other two thrusts were constrained due to COVID19 restrictions on in-person interactions, especially with older adults.

For the first thrust, our focus group worked with clinicians, caregivers and older adults in an elder care facility. All participants expected the SAR to be programmed to be polite and personable, but there was hesitancy around the appearance of the SAR in that it should not look like an alien or too human (what is sometimes called the ?uncanny valley?). The importance of design and programming to meet the individual needs of an older adult either due to their physical or cognitive challenges was an important factor. Clinicians and caregivers also ranked the potential tasks of SARs. The top rankings were: verbally communicates, then mobile, then safe, then uniquely recognizes an older adult. This has strong implications on the design of robots for interacting with older adults in care facilities.

For the second thrust, we worked with an industry partner (Semio AI, Inc.) to provide software for uniquely identifying human users based on a variety of physical features, including their face and perceived gender, age, and body dimensions. A web-based user interface would allow caregivers to provide information about older adults, for whom the SAR would then provide dialog and behaviors personalized to their needs. Using a benchmark dataset, the user identification system achieved 99% classification accuracy based on faces alone; however, when tested on the physical robot in the real world, user identification accuracy based on faces alone was reduced significantly because the SAR was often looking upward at users who were backlit by ceiling lighting, thus, occluding their facial features in shadow. By adding in other factors, such as perceived gender, age, and, most notably, body dimensions, we achieved user identification accuracy of 95%, even in dimly lit environments. This has strong implications for the design of user identification and personalization systems for human-robot interactions.

For the third thrust, due to COVID19, the aims of the project shifted to deploying a SAR at an older adult day care setting for the screening of COVID-19 symptoms and exposure. Despite the focus on older adults, other stakeholders (clinicians and caregivers) were included in the study due to the need for daily COVID-19 screening. The investigation considered which aspects of human-robot-interaction are relevant when designing social agents for patient screening. The implementation was based upon the current screening procedure adopted by the deployment facility, and translated into SAR dialogues and gesturing motion. Post-interaction surveys with participants informed their preferences for the type of interaction and system usability. Observer surveys evaluated users? reaction, verbal and physical engagement. Results indicated general acceptance of the social agent and possible improvements to the current version of the SAR to encourage a broader adoption by the stakeholders.
